introduction.p: To solve a simple radical equation, we raise both sides to the index of the radical.

solution.p: We square both sides of the equation to produce an equation without radicals. \left(\sqrt{x-3}\right)^2 \amp = 4^2 x-3 \amp = 16 x \amp = 19 You can check that x=19 satisfies the original equation.

We first isolate the cube root. -2\sqrt[3]{x-4} \amp = -6 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by}~-2.} \sqrt[3]{x-4} \amp = 3 Next, we undo the cube root by cubing both sides of the equation. \left(\sqrt[3]{x-4}\right)^3 \amp = 3^3 x-4 \amp = 27 Finally, we add 4 to both sides to find the solution, x=31. We do not have to check for extraneous solutions when we cube both sides of an equation, but it is a good idea to check the solution for accuracy anyway.
Check: We substitute \alert{31} for x into the left side of the equation. 2\sqrt[3]{\alert{31}-4} = -2\sqrt[3]{27} = -2(3) = -6 The solutions checks.

introduction.p: We may encounter binomials when squaring both sides of an equation.

statement.p: Explain why \sqrt{x^2}=x is not true for all values of x.

solution.p: Recall that the symbol \sqrt{a} means the non-negative square root of a. If x is a negative number, for example x=-6, then x^2=(-6)^2=36, and not \sqrt{x^2}=\sqrt{36}=6, not -6. So if x is a negative number, \sqrt{x^2}\not= x In fact, \sqrt{x^2}= \abs{x}.

statement.p: For what values of x is ~\sqrt{(x-5)^2} = x-5~?

solution.p: ~\sqrt{(x-5)^2} = x-5~ when x-5 is positive or zero, that is for x \ge 5. If x \lt 5, then x-5 is negative. But the \sqrt{} symbol returns only the positive root, so we use absolute value bars to indicate that the root is positive: \sqrt{(x-5)^2} = \abs{x-5}
